If feeding abilities on each of the 3 seed types are considered as separate characters, then the joint evolution of the 3 feeding behaviors is tightly constrained through beak morphology, known to be highly heritable.-from Author

dc:title: Interspecific competition lowers fitness in collared flycatchers Ficedula albicollis: an experimental demonstration.
dc:creator: Gustafsson L.
dc:description: Reports on a study on the effects of great and blue tits (Parus major, P. caeruleus) on the fitness of collared flycatchers, at natural density, or at artificially high densities. When densities of tits were experimentally reduced, the number and mass of collared flycatcher fledglings increased. Collared flycatchers breeding under reduced competition contributed more recruits to the breeding population than did those breeding in control plots. The mechanism presumably was differential access to food for the young during both the nestling and postfledging periods. The combined fitness value of recruited young and surviving adults was significantly higher in low-competition plots.-from Author

dc:title: Interactions between birds and fruits in a northern Florida hammock community.
dc:creator: Skeate S.
dc:description: Examines interactions between 22 bird species and 45 species of bird-dispersed plants. Frugivore species diversity and abundance were highest during fall and winter. Increases in frugivore numbers and diversity were attributed to the presence of migrant thrushes in the early fall and of overwintering frugivores in late fall and winter. Spring and summer months showed the lowest number of fruting species and fall and winter the highest, with a peak of 28 species in fruit in December. Fruiting patterns fell into 4 seasonal groups; summer, fall, fall-winter, and winter fruiting. Nine species showed summer fruiting, bearing ripe fruit between early spring and late summer. Summer-fruiting species were uncommon in the community and typically occurred in disturbed areas. These species appeared to use both mammals and birds for seed dispersal. The 12 fall-fruiting species ripened fruit at the peak of frugivore migration through N Florida. Fall-fruiting species were common or abundant in the community and depended primarily on migrant thrushes for seed dispersal. The 20 fall-winter fruiting species produced highly persistent fruits that were available to migrant frugivores through fall and winter. The 4 winter-fruiting species matured fruit in December and depended on overwintering birds for seed dispersal. -from Author

dc:title: Herbivory in complex and simple tropical successional ecosystems.
dc:creator: Brown B.
dc:description: Although herbivory rates varied widely among species, losses to herbivores in terms of mass of leaf tissue lost per unit ground area were approximately equal in 4 different systems, 71.5-78.5 g.m-2. yr-1. Ecosystems with greater plant species richness lost a lower proportion of available leaf area and exhibited lower temporal variability in herbivory. Species-rich ecosystems had relatively constant, predictable rates of herbivory due to counterbalancing of low rates on some species with high rates on others. The rate of herbivory on any species was strongly influenced by the nature of the surrounding vegetation. Although surrounding vegetation often conferred protection upon potential pest targets, in some cases a plant species experienced increased susceptibility to herbivores through association with other species. -from Authors

dc:title: Influence of refuging consumers ( pikas: Ochotona princeps) on subalpine meadow vegetation.
dc:creator: Huntly N.
dc:description: Talus slopes in W North America frequently are bordered by vegetation that differs in biomass, cover, height, and species composition from vegetation located farther from talus. These areas are grazed by pikas, which nest in that talus. Foraging theory predicts that pikas will produce a gradient of grazing pressure, which could produce the observed vegetational zonation. In a subalpine meadow in W-central Colorado, pikas produced the predicted gradient of grazing pressure, along which plant groups varied clinally in abundance. -from Author

dc:title: Drosophila population dynamics: chaos and extinction.
dc:creator: Philippi T.
dc:description: Observed fluctuations and extinctions may be explained on the basis of a reduced carrying capacity and an increased variance of growth dynamics (environmental stochasticity). -from Author

dc:title: Seed predation and cross- pollination in mast-seeding beech ( Fagus sylvatica) patches.
dc:creator: Nilsson S.
dc:description: Cross-pollination in this wind-pollinated species is positively correlated with stand size and flower density. In 2 mast years in S Sweden 6-14% of seeds contained no kernels, and in a nonmast year the figure was 24%. Predispersal destruction of seeds by a moth (Cydia fagiglandana) was 3.1% in a mast year and 38% in a nonmast year. Variation in seed destruction by vertebrates was much less between mast (5.7%) and nonmast (12%) years. Destruction by the moth was negatively correlated with tree size, while that by vertebrates was postively correlated with tree size. Vertebrate seed predation was negatively correlated with stand size. In a large stand, <10% of the seeds were consumed by vertebrates by April in 2 mast years. Both cross-pollination and seed predation may have been important factors in the evolution of mast seeding in beech. -from Authors

dc:title: Multiple-species induction of morphological defenses in the rotifer Keratella testudo.
dc:creator: Stemberger R.
dc:description: Filtrates of cultures of 10 of 12 common freshwater zooplankton species induced posterior spines in Keratella testudo. Filtrates of cultures of Asplanchna spp. and those of crustacean zooplankton, including cladocerans and cyclopoid and calanoid copepods, generally produced the strongest induction responses. The filtrates of Daphnia pulex cultures, at densities as low as 0.4 individuals/L, promoted significant posterior spine development. This is the first known case of a competitor-controlled developmental polymorphism in zooplankton. In some, but not all, interactions with inducing species, the posterior-spined Keratella phenotype had higher survivorships than the unspined one. Spined individuals were significantly more protected than unspined ones against injury by mechanical interference by Daphnia.-from Authors

dc:title: Plant community diversity, herbivore movement, and an insect- transmitted disease of maize.
dc:creator: Power A.
dc:description: In Nicaragua, population levels of the corn heafhopper Dalbulus maidis, which transmits the corn stunt spiroplasma to maize, were monitored in: low-density maize monoculture, high-density maize monoculture, two-species (maize/bean) polyculture, and multispecies (maize/weeds) polyculture. Leafhopper abundance per plant and the incidence of corn stunt were lower in high-density maize monocultures than in low-density monocultures. Increasing plant diversity by intercropping with nonhost species also led to lower leafhopper abundance and decreased disease incidence, but the effect was not enhanced as additional nonhost species were added to the community. Higher leafhopper densities occurred at higher N fertilization. Leafhopper movement rates were lowest in the polycultures; across-row movement was strikingly inhibited in the bean polyculture, which also had the highest rates of emigration. That plant quality, density, and diversity significantly affect the spread of corn stunt through their effects on abundance and movement behavior of the corn leafhopper could be manipulated in a program of cultural control.-from Author

dc:title: Population ecology of a desert rodent: Dipodomys merriami in the Chihuahuan Desert.
dc:creator: Zongyong Zeng
dc:description: The life history is characterized by long survival (up to at least 3.5 yr), modest and variable reproductive effort (zero to at least 2 litters per year, and an average of 2 young per litter), slow growth and maturation of young (at least 3 mo from birth to reproductive maturity), and frequent, facultative dispersal of adults as well as juveniles (75% of the males and 59% of the females that lived >4 mo dispersed). This combination of life history traits enabled D. merriami to confine reproduction to favorable periods, with the result that although adults of both sexes showed a loss of body mass associated with reproduction, there was no evidence that they experienced increased risk of mortality.-from Authors

dc:title: Optimal foraging in seed-harvester ants: computer-aided simulation.
dc:creator: Reyes Lopez J.L.
dc:description: Simulation is based on regression studies of running speed, net cost of transport, worker size, load mass, and distance. As a function of its size, each worker has a maximum transport yield and an upper load limit. For yields other than this maximum those obtained by larger workers transporting small loads are less than those obtained if the same loads are transported by smaller workers.-from Author

dc:title: Comparative population dynamics of two goldenrod aphids: spatial patterns and temporal constancy.
dc:creator: Cappuccino N.
dc:description: Uroleucon nigrotuberculatum and U. caligatum, that feed on Solidago altissima, are similar in life histories and feeding habits, but U. caligatum typically occurred in small colonies scattered throughout goldenrod fields, and its numbers remained relatively constant through time, whereas U. nigrotuberculatum occurred in dense colonies and exhibited greater fluctuations in population size. The aggregated spatial pattern of U. nigrotuberculatum resulted from both active aggregation of alates and lack of dispersal by apterae and nymphs. Feeding in large colonies provided no reproductive advantage to either species. Aggregation did, however, enhance aphid survivorship when generalist predators were the main mortality agents; U. nigrotuberculatum was more susceptible to generalist predators. The advantage was reversed later in the season when the aphids' fungal pathogen was present; aggregation then led to a decrease in survivorship. Thus, aggregation allowed a numerical escape from generalist predators but also promoted fungal epidemics, so that the temporal variability in U. nigrotuberculatum populations was largely a consequence of its spatial distribution.-from Author

dc:title: Biomass and nutrient accumulation during stand development in Wyoming lodgepole pine forests.
dc:creator: Pearson J.
dc:description: Maximum total biomass accumulation rates of 2.5-3.2 Mg.ha-1.yr-1 were reached between ages 40-60 yr in even-aged Pinus contorta ssp. latifolia stands, but an uneven-aged stand did not achieve a maximum accumulation rate (1.5 Mg.ha-1.yr-1) until after 80 yr of development. The results suggest a major role for forest floor detritus in the retention of N, P, Ca, and Mg; the importance of living vegetation for K retention; and the fundamental differences in biomass and nutrient dynamics between even-aged stands that develop after fire and stands that develop through gradual invasion of a meadow.-from Authors

dc:title: Role of tannins in defending plants against ruminants: reduction in dry matter digestion.
dc:creator: Robbins C.T.
dc:description: While the apparent digestibility of protein and, therefore, cell solubles is reduced in mule deer Odocoileus hemionus, and white-tailed deer O. virginianus consuming tanniferous forages, digestion of the plant cell wall is not reduced beyond that predicted from its content of lignin, cutin, and silica. Herbivores adapted to consume tanniferous forages may defend against such allelochemicals by producing salivary proteins that bind tannins in a highly specific manner. The occurrence of such proteins in ruminants is reported for the first time.-from Authors

dc:title: Facilitative and inhibitory interactions among estuarine meiobenthic harpacticoid copepods.
dc:creator: Chandler G.T.
dc:description: In the meiofauna communities of Louisiana estuaries, Scottolana canadensis is a semisessile burrow-dweller capable of subsurface suspension and deposit feeding. Pseudostenhelia wellsi is also semisessile but builds extensive networks of mucus tubes within the top 1cm of muddy sediments, and appears to graze on its inner tubewalls. Tube building by P. wellsi generates meiofauna-sized structure and adds cohesiveness to surface sediments, as well as providing potential food and grazing substrates for other meiofauna. Monospecific patches of P. wellsi and S. canadensis were generated in microcosms to determine if the unique lifestyle and sedimentary effects of either species facilitate or inhibit colonization by 2 other errant, burrowing harpacticoids common in the community, Nitocra lacustris and Cletocamptus deitersi. These species share similar foraging and burrowing behaviors and similar effects on sediment structure, which sharply contrast with those of P. wellsi and S. canadensis. P. wellsi tube patches facilitated colonization by both S. canadensis and N. lacustris, but strongly inhibited colonization by C. deitersi. Scottolana canadensis patches were unattractive to N. lacustris. Both mucus enrichment and inert tube structure acted as strong facilitants to N. lacustris copepodites and adults overall.-from Authors

dc:title: Competitive interactions among adults and juveniles in a coral reef fish.
dc:creator: Jones G.
dc:description: Measured the relative effects of recruitment and subsequent intraspecific competition on populations of the planktivorous damselfish Pomacentrus amboinensis, a common species on the Great Barrier Reef. Postrecruitment competitive processes play an important role in restricting adult population size. Competition does not appear to modify recruitment or mortality patterns directly, but influences numbers maturing through density-dependent effects on maturation time.-from Author

dc:title: Influence of moisture, temperature, and substrate on snapping turtle eggs and embryos.
dc:creator: Packard G.C.
dc:description: Chelydra serpentina hatching success was high on wet substrates at 26.0o and 28.5o, but declined at 31.0oC and on drier media. Net absorption of water by viable eggs, duration of incubation by embryos, and size of hatchlings were positively correlated with wetness of substrates and negatively correlated with temperature. Turtles hatching from eggs at 26.0o were males regardless of the wetness of the medium: those emerging from eggs at 28.5o and 31.0o were females.-from Authors

dc:title: Treefalls revisited: gap dynamics in the southern Appalachians.
dc:creator: Runkle J.
dc:description: In 1976-1977, 284 gaps (canopy-opening sizes 1-1490 m2) were sampled (age, size, species composition) from old-growth mesic forests in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, Joyce Kilmer Wilderness Area and Walker Cove Research Natural Area. In 1983, the woody vegetation (stems = or >1 cm dbh) of 273 of these gaps was resampled, rates of gap closure by canopy tree branch growth and sapling height growth were estimated, and incidences of disturbances occurring since 1976-1977 were noted. Average yearly crown extension growth rate was 18 cm/yr in height, again with much variation among species and individuals. Saplings grew an average of 30 cm/yr in height, again with much variation. Overall, taller saplings grew somewhat faster than smaller ones and saplings in large gaps grew faster than those in small gaps. Most saplings will thus require = or >2 gap episodes to reach the forest canopy. For woody vegetation, basal area per unit gap area was originally highest in small gaps, though it increased between sampling dates most in large gaps. Stem density had been highest in small old gaps, but decreased the most in old gaps. Tsuga canadensis, Fagus grandifolia, Acer saccharum and Halesia carolina were the most important species in the gaps. Overall, Tsuga and Fagus decreased and A. saccharum increased in importance. High rates of repeat disturbance favor species able to grow in intermediate light levels and to survive several periods of suppression before reaching the canopy. -from Authors

dc:title: Differentiation among nine populations of Phlox: response to environmental gradients.
dc:creator: Schwaegerle K.
dc:description: In Phlox drummondii, statistically significant heterogeneity among populations in survival, vegetative growth and flowering was observed in response to different levels of moisture, light, nutrients, and competition. Differences in germination were observed in response to temperature and nutrient levels. Some populations are more sensitive to different environments than others, a significant genotype-environment interaction. -from Authors

dc:title: Evaluation of character displacement among plants in two tropical pollination guilds.
dc:creator: Murray K.
dc:description: In cloud forest at Monteverde, Costa Rica, 2 guilds of bird-pollinated plants exist, one pollinated by long-billed hummingbirds, primarily green hermit Phaethornis guy and one by short-billed hummingbirds, primarily purple-throated mountain-gem Lampornis calolaema. Plants were assigned to guilds based on hummingbird visit patterns. Neither guild exhibited pronounced character displacement. Absence of pattern is attributed to the following aspects of biological variability: 1) within any one year, density-dependent competition for pollination is sporadic, and is not clearly related to flowering season or morphological similarity; 2) the nature of interspecific interactions varies among years, as neither the relative intensities of flowering nor the flowering seasons themselves are consistent from year to year; 3) the nature of interspecific interactions varies with changes in species composition, which occur over short distances; 4) the assemblage of species is probably not stable over long time spans.-from Authors

dc:title: Larval dispersion and survivorship in a leaf-mining moth.
dc:creator: Simberloff D.
dc:description: Stilbosis quadricustatella (Lepidoptera: Cosmopterygidae) exhibited a clumped distribution of mines among leaves of the evergreen sand-live oak Quercus geminata. Mines tended to be on large, peripheral, and undamaged leaves so that leaves were often multiply mined. Unless miners in an abscised leaf were very near to pupation, abscission killed them. Premature leaf fall was by far the largest source of larval mortality for this moth. Clumping of miners was no more favourable to the tree (in terms of number of leaves abscised early) than to the insect.-from Authors

dc:title: An approach to the perturbation analysis of optimal life histories.
dc:creator: Caswell H.
dc:description: Presents a method for calculating the perturbation response of a constrained optimum when the constraint function is at least approximately linear. Examples are used from life-history theory, but the method is widely applicable. Even for simple two-variable optimization problems, subject to linear costraints, the response to perturbations is surprisingly indeterminate and sometimes counter-intuitive. This indeterminancy is resolved by the values of the second derivatives of fitness with respect to its components. -from Authors

dc:title: The influence of food supply on local density and diversity of sparrows.
dc:creator: Pulliam H.
dc:description: In an arid oak woodland in SE Arizona, local population density of sparrows (Emberizinae) is independent of local seed abundance during years of moderate to high seed production.-from Authors

dc:title: A stage-based population model for loggerhead sea turtles and implications for conservation.
dc:creator: Crouse D.
dc:description: Current management practices appear to be focused on the least responsive life stage, eggs on nesting beaches. Alternative protection efforts for juvenile Caretta caretta, such as using turtle excluder devices, may be far more effective.-from Authors

dc:title: Ecological consequences of an exceptionally strong El Nino event on Darwin's finches.
dc:creator: Gibbs H.
dc:description: Examined the effects of heavy rainfall associated with the El Nino event of 1982-1983 on the demography of Geospizinae populations and their resources on Isla Daphne Major, Galapagos. Total rainfall during this period (1359 mm) was 10 times the previously recorded wet season maximum. Most plant species responded by dramatically increasing seed production; total seed biomass increased by an order of magnitude, and small seed biomass increased in relative abundance, from 20% of total seed biomass before 1983 to >80% at the peak of the event. Caterpillars, the main food used by finches while breeding, also became extremely abundant. Medium ground finch Geospiza fortis and cactus finch G. scandens responded to the increase of food supply by breeding repeatedly. Females produced up to 10 clutches of eggs; normally they produce 1-5 clutches. Some birds born at the beginning of the season bred successfully before the end. The large number of young produced resulted in 1) increases in population sizes of both species by a factor of 4; 2) a dramatic skew in the age structure of both species; and 3) >50% of the lifetime fledgling production of females born in 198 occurring in this breeding season. Individuals of both species immigrated from nearby islands, and the nonresident large ground finch (G. magnirostris) immigrated and bred on the island.-from Authors

dc:title: Seedling recruitment strategies in obligate-seeding and resprouting Banksia shrubs.
dc:creator: Zammit C.
dc:description: Banksia ericifolia is killed by fire and so depends upon seeds for persistence; B. oblongifolia can persist after fire by resprouting from protected buds, as well as by recruiting seedlings. These serotinous species coexist in the fire-prone scrublands of the Sydney Basin. B. oblongifolia seeds were released more quickly than B. ericifolia seeds after a fire, and B. oblongifolia follicles opened and shed seeds after exposure to lower temperatures than those of B. ericifolia. B. oblongifolia seeds also germinated more quickly. The relative growth rates and leaf mass ratios (mean ratio of leaf dry mass to plant dry mass over sequential harvests) of the species did not differ. Root:shoot ratios were significantly larger and biomass allocation to roots was faster in B. oblongifolia seedlings. B. ericifolia seedlings survived low and intermediate levels of droughting better than B. oblongifolia, and where water was not limiting, large B. oblongifolia seedings had the highest survival rate. Selection has acted on B. ericifolia to minimize the chance of zero seedling survival by distributing the risks over more than one germination episode.-from Authors

dc:title: Regulation of seed yield within and among populations of Prunella vulgaris.
dc:creator: Winn A.A.
dc:description: Much of the variation in total yield among individuals within populations could be explained by differences in plant size. In general, relationships between components of yield were weak, indicating that total yield was not tightly buffered by trade-offs among yield components. The pattern of relationships between yield components differed among populations, demonstrating that these relationships are not a constant characteristic of a species. The patterns of relationship between each component and an estimate of the number of successful seedlings produced also differed among populations. but seed number was generally more important than biomass per seed in determining plant fitness. Populations in woodland habitats tended to produce fewer flowers per inflorescence and larger seeds than populations in old-field habitats, differences due to phenotypic plasticity. Variation among populations in mean yield was buffered by a trade-off between the numbers of flowers per inflorescence and seed mass.-from Authors

dc:title: Regulation of structure in complex systems: experimental temporary pond communities.
dc:creator: Wilbur H.
dc:description: Hatchlings of Rana utricularia, Scaphiopus holbrooki, Bufo americanus and Hyla chrysoscelis were introduced at the same relative abundances at a low or a high initial density. Competition determined survival, body size at metamorphosis, and length of larval period in high-density communities, which were food-limited. The predatory salamander Notophthalmus viridescens did not alter either the total number of metamorphs or their combined biomass in high-density communities, but the relative abundance of metamorphs was shifted as S. holbrooki, the competitive dominant, was selectively eaten. In low-density communities, predation decreased survival and biomass production of tadpoles, often to zero, in all species. Competition slowed growth and thus increased the risk of desiccation in high-density populations in drying ponds. Predation ameliorated the effects of competition, allowing survivors to grow rapidly enough to metamorphose before ponds dried. Survival of tadpoles to metamorphosis, body size at metamorphosis, and time of metamorphosis were determined in a complex way by interactions among all of the treatment effects and the life history characteristics of the 4 species.-from Author

dc:title: Can competition be detected using species co-occurrence data?
dc:creator: Hastings A.
dc:description: Determined the equilibrium structure of a model of competition with an arbitrary number of species. Species were assumed to live on a large number of identical islands (patches), and all species were assumed to have similar characteristics. In model systems, competition was included by letting the per species extinction rate on patches increase with the number of species. With reasonable sample sizes and strong competition, it is not possible to show statistically that the resulting species distributions differ from random assortment. In more realistic situations where species and islands differ, competition would be even more difficult to detect, so using species co-occurrence data to look for competition is likely not to detect even strong competition. -Author

dc:title: Insect herbivory and photosynthetic pathways in old-field ecosystems.
dc:creator: Pinder J.E.
dc:description: Three old-field plant communities of varying composition near Aiken, South Carolina, were used to test the hypothesis that phytophagous insects avoid consuming plants possessing the C4 photosynthetic pathway and consume plants that possess only the C3 pathway. In one community, the carbon isotope ratio for insects was significantly less than that expected for proportional consumption and indicated avoidance of C4 species. Insect consumption of C4 plants was c 50% of that expected if insects were consuming C3 and C4 plants in proportion to their abundance. In the other 2 communities, differences between observed and expected isotopic ratios were not significant. Levels of insect consumption of C4 plants in these 2 communities were, respectively, 82% and 126% of those expected for proportional consumption consumption. Degree of avoidance thus probably varies among plant communities. -from Authors

dc:title: Litter placement effects on microbial and organic matter dynamics in an agroecosystem.
dc:creator: Holland E.A.
dc:description: Two different agricultural tillage practices were used to study how changes in the structure of the soil-litter system affected litter decomposition rates, microbial community composition, and soil organic matter dynamics. Surface placement of straw in no-till agriculture allowed management of microclimate and microbial populations so that losses of soil organic matter and nutrients were minimized. -from Authors

dc:title: Old-field succession on a Minnesota sand plain.
dc:creator: Inouye R.
dc:description: Soil N concentration increased significantly with field age. Vegetation cover, total aboveground plant biomass, and litter cover increased significantly with soil N. Light penetration to the soil surface was negatively correlated with total plant biomass. Species richness per field and within field heterogeneity in species composition increased with field age. Local species richness decreased with increasing soil N. Cover of annuals and introduced species decreased with field age and N, but annuals contributed an important part of total vegetative cover even in 25yr old fields. Cover of perennials and woody species increased with soil N and field age. Although the fields were bordered by woods, woody species contributed <15% cover even in the oldest fields. While soil N is an important determinant of local species composition and abundance, dispersal and colonization, which are dependent on field age, nevertheless determine which species are present in a field. -from Authors
